Available online 20 May 2022 Article Heterostructuring 2D TiO2 nanosheets in situ grown on Ti3C2T x MXene to improve the electrocatalytic nitrogen reduction Xiu Qian a Yanjiao Wei a Mengjie Sun a Ye Han a * Xiaoli Zhang d Jian Tian a b # Minhua Shao b c $ a School of Materials Science and Engineering, Shandong University of Science and Technology, Qingdao 266590, Shandong, China School of Materials Science and Engineering Shandong University of Science and Technology Qingdao Shandong 266590 China School of Materials Science and Engineering, Shandong University of Science and Technology, Qingdao 266590, Shandong, China b Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering, The Hong Kong University of Science and Technology, Clear Water Bay, Kowloon, Hong Kong, China Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering The Hong Kong University of Science and Technology Clear Water Bay Kowloon Hong Kong China Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering, The Hong Kong University of Science and Technology, Clear Water Bay, Kowloon, Hong Kong, China c Energy Institute, and Chinese National Engineering Research Center for Control & Treatment of Heavy Metal Pollution, The Hong Kong University of Science and Technology, Clear Water Bay, Kowloon, Hong Kong, China Energy Institute, and Chinese National Engineering Research Center for Control & Treatment of Heavy Metal Pollution The Hong Kong University of Science and Technology Clear Water Bay Kowloon Hong Kong China Energy Institute, and Chinese National Engineering Research Center for Control & Treatment of Heavy Metal Pollution, The Hong Kong University of Science and Technology, Clear Water Bay, Kowloon, Hong Kong, China d School of Materials Science and Engineering, Zhengzhou University, Zhengzhou 450001, Henan, China School of Materials Science and Engineering Zhengzhou University Zhengzhou Henan 450001 China School of Materials Science and Engineering, Zhengzhou University, Zhengzhou 450001, Henan, China * Corresponding author # Corresponding author $ Corresponding author In this study, TiO2 nanosheets (NSs) grown in situ on extremely conductive Ti3C2T x MXene to form TiO2/Ti3C2T x MXene composites with abundant active sites are proposed to effectively achieve electrocatalytic NH3 synthesis. Electron transfer can be promoted by Ti3C2T x MXene with high conductivity. Meanwhile, the TiO2 NSs in-situ formation can not only avoid Ti3C2T x MXene microstacking but also enhance the surface specific area of Ti3C2T x MXene. The TiO2/Ti3C2T x MXene catalyst reaches a high Faradaic efficiency (FE) of 44.68% at −0.75 V vs. RHE and a large NH3 yield of 44.17 µg h−1 mg−1 cat. at −0.95 V, with strong electrochemical durability. 15N isotopic labeling experiments imply that the N in the produced NH3 originated from the N2 of the electrolyte. DFT calculations were conducted to determine the possible NRR reaction pathways for TiO2/Ti3C2T x MXene composites. MXene catalysts combined with other materials have been rationally designed for efficient ammonia production under ambient conditions. Graphical Abstract TiO2/Ti3C2T x MXene was prepared through the in situ growth of TiO2 nanosheets (NSs) on extremely conductive Ti3C2T x MXene, which exhibited an excellent electrochemical activity for NRR (NH3 yield of 44.17 µg h−1 mg−1 cat.). Keywords Electrocatalyst N2 reduction reaction TiO2 nanosheet Ti3C2T x MXene In-situ growth 1 Introduction As an essential activated nitrogen source, NH3 plays a vital role in polymers, textile industries, industrial manufacturing, and agricultural cultivation [1,2]. Owing to its considerable hydrogen capacity and high energy density [3], NH3 is one of the greenest and most ideal energy carriers, even as a substitute for H2 in the future energy economy, and it has also been considered a carbon-neutral energy-intensive carrier that will greatly promote the global carbon cycle [4]. Abundant nitrogen (N2) is the main raw material for synthesizing NH3, but the extremely high cleavage energy of N≡N triple bonds makes the nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR) extremely difficult [5,6]. Currently, NH3 production is mainly achieved using the Haber-Bosch method, which consumes high energy [7]. Therefore, the design of a sustainable approach to the N2-fixation strategy operated under mild pressure and temperature is needed [8–11]. The electrocatalytic NRR is a potential substitute for the Haber-Bosch method for NH3 synthesis because it can operate under ambient conditions and uses renewable raw materials such as N2 and water [12–16]. To date, although noble metals have exhibited an excellent electrocatalytic NRR activity, their high cost and low abundance limit their wide applications [17,18]. Research on NRR electrocatalysts has recently shifted to inexpensive and abundant transition metal oxides, including Cr2O3, Nb2O5, α-Fe2O3, MoO3, Fe3O4, Fe2O3, TiO2-rGO, α-Fe@Fe3O4, Bi4V2O11/CeO2, Fe/Fe3O4, and TiO2/Ti [19–21]. It is necessary to develop an ideal electrocatalyst that simultaneously meets the requirements of a high NH3 yield, remarkable selectivity, strong durability, and energy saving [22,23]. As an emerging 2D material, the chemical formula of MXene can be recorded as M n+1X n T x (n = 1, 2, and 3), where “M” represents transition metals (such as V, Ta, Mo, Ti, and Nb), whereas “X” indicates N or C or CN, and “T x ” presents surface functional groups (such as –O, –F, and –OH) [24,25]. Owing to its unique layered structure, excellent conductivity, flexibility, and hydrophilic surface, MXene has shown remarkable applications in catalysis, supercapacitors, biosensors, electronic devices, electromagnetic wave absorption, lithium-ion batteries, and energy storage fields. Owing to its remarkable conductivity and stability, Ti3C2T x MXene has proven to be a promising NRR catalyst based on theoretical calculations and experimental results [25]. However, to meet the demands of the NH3 industry, there is still a large gap to be filled in terms of both NH3 yield and NRR selectivity prior to practical application [15,26]. The lamellar structure of MXene is easy to stack, which reduces the specific surface area and affects the diffusion of ions between layers, resulting in a decrease in the electrochemical performance. An effective method to reduce the stacking of layers is to assemble them with other materials. The edge Ti atoms on the surface of Ti3C2T x MXene can serve as nucleation sites to generate relatively stable TiO2; thus, a heterojunction structure of TiO2 nanosheets (NSs) distributed in 2D Ti3C2T x MXene (TiO2/Ti3C2T x MXene) can easily be formed. Herein, TiO2 nanosheets were generated in situ on Ti3C2T x MXene to form TiO2/Ti3C2T x MXene composites through a one-step hydrothermal process. The TiO2/Ti3C2T x MXene catalyst achieved an NH3 yield of 44.17 µg h−1 mg−1 cat. at −0.95 V and an FE of 44.68% at −0.75 V, which are better than pure Ti3C2T x MXene (NH3 yield of 23.61 µg h−1 mg−1 cat., FE of 5.10%) and pure TiO2 NSs (NH3 yield of 26.23 µg h−1 mg−1 cat., FE of 1.54%), together with an excellent stability and durability. 2 Results and discussion Scheme 1 shows the preparation process for TiO2/Ti3C2T x MXene composites. Initially, through the selective etching of the Al layers of Ti3AlC2, multilayer Ti3C2T x MXene was obtained through the previously reported HF etching method [27,28]. Later, because the edge Ti atoms on the Ti3C2T x MXene surface can serve as nucleating sites to generate relatively stable TiO2, the TiO2 nanosheets generated in situ on the layered Ti3C2T x MXene (TiO2/Ti3C2T x MXene) were prepared through a one-step hydrothermal oxidation treatment of Ti3C2T x MXene with the assistance of HCl and NaBF4. Fig. 1 shows the X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the samples. The Ti3AlC2 presents an excellent crystallinity (curve green), and the most intense peak at ~38.77° corresponds to the (104) plane of Ti3AlC2 (JCPDS No. 52-0875) [29]. After etching Al layers with HF, the strongest peak of Ti3AlC2 at 38.77° entirely disappears (curve orange). In addition, the (004) plane of Ti3AlC2 at 19.07° is broadened, owing to the interlayer spacing extension, indicating that the Al layers are successfully removed and Ti3C2T x MXene is formed [30,31]. Compared with an untreated Ti3C2T x MXene sample, the diffraction peaks of anatase TiO2 are observed after the hydrothermal oxidation of Ti3C2T x MXene (curve purple, JCPDS No. 21-1272) [32], which proves the successful generation of TiO2 NSs on Ti3C2T x MXene. As shown in the full-scale XPS survey spectrum (Fig. 2(a) ), Ti, C, and O can be seen in the TiO2/Ti3C2T x MXene composites, where the F element is ascribed to the F− ions from the HF solution physically adsorbed on the composites. Figs. 2(b)–(d) show the XPS analysis of O, C, and Ti from the TiO2/Ti3C2T x MXene composites. The Ti 2p spectrum of TiO2/Ti3C2T x MXene is deconvoluted into four peaks (Fig. 2(b)), in which 458.10 (Ti 2p 1/2) and 453.85 (Ti 2p 3/2) eV can be assigned to the Ti–C bonds of Ti3C2T x MXene, whereas the other two peaks at 463.75 eV (Ti 2p 1/2) and 456.60 eV (Ti 2p 3/2) are ascribed to the lattice Ti–O bonds of TiO2 [33,34]. The simultaneous existence of Ti–C bonds and Ti–O bonds proves the successful preparation of the TiO2/Ti3C2T x MXene composites. For the C 1s spectrum (Fig. 2(c)), the three peaks at 287.60, 283.65, and 280.20 eV are ascribed to the C–O–C, C–C, and C–Ti bonds, respectively [35,36]. In addition, for the O 1s spectrum of TiO2/Ti3C2T x MXene composites (Fig. 2(d)), three peaks at 529.15, 530.79, and 532.38 eV were detected, corresponding to the O-Ti, C-Ti-O x , and surface hydroxyl groups (–OH), respectively [32,37,38]. The morphologies and microscopic structures of Ti3C2T x MXene and TiO2/Ti3C2T x MXene were further elucidated using SEM and TEM, respectively. The morphology of bulk Ti3AlC2 was clearly observed using SEM (Fig. S1). As shown in Fig. 3(a) , the typical exfoliated 2D morphology of Ti3C2T x MXene can be determined through SEM characterization by etching the Al layer of bulk Ti3AlC2 with HF [39]. Because MXene contains thermodynamically stable edge transition metal atoms, after the hydrothermal oxidation of Ti3C2T x MXenes with HCl and NaBF4, the layered Ti3C2T x MXene offers Ti sources for the generation of TiO2, thus enabling TiO2 NSs to cross the Ti3C2T x MXene layer and form TiO2/Ti3C2T x MXene composites. It can be clearly seen from Fig. 3(b) that many nanosheets are formed on the surface of Ti3C2T x MXene, indicating that the TiO2 NSs were successfully grown on the surface of Ti3C2T x MXene. These nanosheets are anatase TiO2 with exposed (101) surfaces [17]. More importantly, the TiO2 NSs uniformly distributed around the layered Ti3C2T x MXene can provide more active sites for the NRR, which is beneficial for improving the electrocatalytic performance. To investigate the effect of active sites on the NRR, we conducted a BET analysis and electrochemical surface area (ESCA) measurements. TiO2/Ti3C2T x MXene presents a larger BET surface area (14.72 m2 g−1) than Ti3C2T x MXene (1.98 m2 g−1) and pure TiO2 NSs (10.197 m2 g−1) (Fig. S2), and the ECSA of TiO2/Ti3C2T x MXene is 0.3826 cm2, which is better than that of TiO2 NSs (0.0028 cm2) and Ti3C2T x MXene (0.301 cm2), suggesting that TiO2/Ti3C2T x MXene possesses more active sites (Fig. S3). In addition, the heterostructure formed by TiO2 and Ti3C2T x MXene was beneficial for the ions between layers. The enhanced electrical conductivity was confirmed through electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) spectra in the NRR (Fig. S4). In Nyquist plots, a small arc radius represents a small charge-transfer resistance. As shown in Fig. S4, compared with TiO2, a smaller arc radius was obtained for TiO2/Ti3C2T x MXene, which proves that the heterostructure formed by TiO2 NSs and Ti3C2T x MXene promotes electron transfer. TEM images further confirmed the morphology and microscopic structure of TiO2/Ti3C2T x MXene composites. It can be observed that square TiO2 was interspersed in the large-layered Ti3C2T x MXene in the TiO2/Ti3C2T x MXene composites (Fig. 3(c)). As shown in Fig. 3(d), two types of lattice fringes can be clearly observed in the TiO2/Ti3C2T x MXene composites, one with a lattice spacing of 0.23 nm resulting from the (103) crystal facet of Ti3C2T x MXene, and the other with an interplanar spacing of 0.35 nm accurately assigned to the (101) lattice of anatase TiO2 [40–42]. Lattice fringes of Ti3C2T x MXene and TiO2 were clearly observed, indicating that TiO2/Ti3C2T x MXene composites were successfully prepared. The selected-area TEM image and corresponding EDX mapping images (Fig. 3(e)) imply the homogenous distribution of Ti, C, and O, which is consistent with the XPS survey spectrum (Fig. 2(a)). To test the NRR activity of TiO2/Ti3C2T x MXene composites, electrochemical measurements were conducted under ambient conditions in 0.1 mol/L Na2SO4 (pH = 6) with an H-type electrolytic cell by separating a Nafion membrane [43]. The experimental apparatus used for electrocatalysis of the NRR is shown in Fig. S5. First, the LSV curves of TiO2/Ti3C2T x MXene were operated at a sweep rate of 5 mV s−1 under Ar- and N2-saturated 0.1 mol/L Na2SO4 solution, respectively (Fig. S6). A higher current density was observed in the N2-saturated solution than in the Ar-saturated solution, implying that N2 can be reduced to NH3 by the as-prepared TiO2/Ti3C2T x MXene catalyst. As shown in the inset in Fig. S6, the difference in the current density is particularly noticeable from −0.7 to −1.0 V vs. RHE, indicating the possible activity of a TiO2/Ti3C2T x MXene catalyst for N2 electroreduction. As shown in the chronoamperometry curves (Fig. 4(a) ), the current density increased with an increase in the potentials from −0.75 to −1.0 V vs. RHE. The current density is stable and scarcely alters from −0.75 to −0.95 V, indicating an excellent durability. However, the I-t curve at −1.0 V violently vibrates owing to the formation of H2 gas. The UV-Vis absorption spectra of various concentrations of a standard NH3 solution and the corresponding calibration curves (y = 0.509x + 0.105, R 2 = 0.999) for NH3 quantification are shown in Fig. S7. The NH4 + concentration was quantified using the calibrated indophenol-blue method [44]. The average NH3 yield and FE of TiO2/Ti3C2T x MXene at different applied potentials are shown in Fig. 4(b). After electrolysis of TiO2/Ti3C2T x MXene as the catalyst for 2 h, the highest absorbance appears at −0.95 V at 655 nm, suggesting the highest ammonia yield (Fig. 4(c)). The highest NH3 yield can be realized at −0.95 V, where the value is 44.17 µg h−1 mg−1 cat., suggesting that TiO2/Ti3C2T x MXene exhibits an advanced NRR performance among the reported MXene-based electrocatalysts (Table S1). The NH3 yields increase with a negatively applied potential until −0.95 V, and then gradually decrease. When the potential is more negative (−1.00 V), the NH3 yields decrease owing to the increased HER [45], thus taking up the active sites on the electrocatalyst surface. The FE gradually decreases when the applied potential becomes more negative. The highest FE value (44.68%) can be achieved at −0.75 V. In fact, the current density increases significantly with increasingly applied potentials because of the dominance of the HER at higher overpotentials, which results in a decrease in FEs (Fig. 4(a)). The highest ammonia yield rate is as high as 44.17 µg h−1 mg−1 cat. at −0.95 V, whereas the FE for TiO2/Ti3C2T x MXene at −0.95 V is low. A reasonable explanation for this is that the solubility of N2 in water is extremely low, and the NRR is controlled through N2 diffusion in this system. At higher negative potentials, the surface of TiO2/Ti3C2T x MXene is primarily occupied by the generated H molecules because of the dominance of the HER, which prevents N2 from transferring to the surface of TiO2/Ti3C2T x MXene, thereby limiting the electrocatalytic NRR activity. The NRR electrocatalytic activities of Ti3C2T x MXene and pure TiO2 NSs on a GCE were also studied for comparison. After 2 h of electrolysis using pure TiO2 NSs and pure Ti3C2T x MXene as the catalysts, the average NH3 yield and the corresponding FE at −0.95 V are measured (Fig. 4(d)). The NH3 yields and FEs of TiO2 (NH3 yield of 34.11 µg mg−1 cat. h−1; FE of 3.71% at −0.95 vs. RHE) and Ti3C2T x MXene (NH3 yield of 34.55 µg mg−1 cat. h−1; FE of 5.59% at −0.95 vs. RHE) were lower than those of TiO2/Ti3C2T x MXene (NH3 yield of 44.17 µg mg−1 cat. h−1; FE of 5.97% at −0.95 vs. RHE). Moreover, NRR tests were carried out for a simple mixture of TiO2 NSs and Ti3C2T x MXene, and its NH3 yield and FE were lower than those of the TiO2/Ti3C2T x MXene composites (Fig. S8). The comparison experiments show that TiO2/Ti3C2T x MXene presents a more improved NRR property than pure TiO2 NSs, pure Ti3C2T x MXene, and a simple mixture of TiO2 NSs and Ti3C2T x MXene, which proves that the improvement of the NRR performance is due to the structural advantages of the self-growth of TiO2 NSs. Stability is a key factor in estimating the NRR activity of electrocatalysts. The results of the recycling experiment (Fig. 5(a) ) indicated that TiO2/Ti3C2T x MXene presents a relatively stable NRR property. Successive electrolysis for 12 h at a constant potential of −0.95 V results in only a small current density loss and unremarkable decay of the NH3 yield and FE (Figs. 5(b) and S9), indicating that TiO2/Ti3C2T x MXene exhibits superior long-term electrochemical durability during the NRR process. The XRD analysis after NRR electrolysis (Fig. S10) demonstrates that this catalyst exhibits no change in the crystalline phase after NRR electrolysis, implying that it is extremely stable during the NRR process. SEM images (Fig. S11) also showed that the morphology of TiO2/Ti3C2T x MXene remained unchanged after NRR electrolysis. Therefore, the as-prepared TiO2/Ti3C2T x MXene was a highly stable NRR electrocatalyst. In addition, the approximately unchanged NH3 yields and FEs were unaffected by the variation in N2 flow rates, suggesting that the N2 flow is not a step that determines the reaction rate in this electrocatalytic process (Fig. 5(c)). Isotope labeling experiments were conducted to elucidate the origin of ammonia. The 1H NMR spectrum shows a specific double peak for 15NH4 + and three 14NH4 + signals (Fig. 5(d)) using 14N2 and 15N2 as N2 sources, respectively, indicating that the detected NH3 was generated through an electrocatalytic N2 reduction. Furthermore, N2H4, regarded as a possible by-product, was determined using the Chrisp-Watt method. A standard calibration curve for the N2H4 assay is shown in Fig. S12. The UV-Vis absorption spectrum of the electrolytes after NRR at −0.95 V is provided in Fig. S13 [46]. As indicated, N2H4 cannot be clearly distinguished in the N2-saturated electrolyte, suggesting that the TiO2/Ti3C2T x MXene catalyst exhibited an excellent selectivity for NH3 production. To confirm that NH3 is produced by the NRR of TiO2/Ti3C2T x MXene rather than from the environment, instruments, or reactants, we conducted control experiments in which only one parameter was changed and the other conditions were kept unchanged [24,47]. Before the test, N2 was sufficiently purified, which was purged through a 1 mmol/L H2SO4 solution, followed by 0.1 mol/L KOH to eliminate possible NH3 and NO x impurities in all measurements conducted in this study. The pretreated N2 was bubbled into a cathode chamber for 30 min, and no obvious UV-Vis absorption spectrum of the electrolytes for NH3 was observed using the indophenol blue method, indicating that the experiment results were barely affected by the supplied gas (Fig. S14). Electrolysis was also carried out in an Ar-saturated electrolyte at −0.95 V for 2 h, and the corresponding UV-Vis absorption spectrum (Fig. S15) is extremely close to that of a blank electrolyte, indicating that the formation of NH3 is neither from the self-electrolysis of the catalysts nor the contamination of the electrolytes. To further confirm that NH3 is produced through the NRR of TiO2/Ti3C2T x MXene, we also carry out the test in a N2-saturated solution under an open circuit potential at −0.95 V for 2 h (curved black line in Fig. S16), indicating that almost no NH3 is detected. To exclude the catalytic performance of a glassy carbon electrode, we applied a N2 electrocatalysis over the electrode at −0.95 V; in addition, the production of NH3 also cannot be determined, indicating that it has no contribution to the NRR performance (curved red line in Fig. S16). These results indicate that the detected NH3 was fully produced by the NRR. The contribution of the self-electrolysis of catalysts, contamination of electrolytes, and the surrounding environment are almost negligible in the laboratory. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations were conducted to further investigate the possible NRR pathways in TiO2/Ti3C2T x MXene composites. The stable adsorption models of the NRR on pure TiO2 and the TiO2/Ti3C2T x MXene composites are shown in Fig. S17. The NRR kinetic pathway was investigated based on the calculated Gibbs free energy (ΔG) diagrams. Two possible NRR pathways were proposed: the distal and alternative pathways (Figs. 6(a) and (b) ). The adsorption geometries of other important intermediates are shown in Figs. S18 and S19. Therefore, the NRR pathways on the pure TiO2 and TiO2/Ti3C2T x MXene composites were evaluated using DFT. It can be seen that the energetically most difficult step or potential-determining step (PDS) corresponds to hydrogenation of adsorbed *NNH2 to form an *N intermediate (Figs. S20 and S21). In the distal pathways, the *NNH2 into *N process is an uphill pathway with ΔG = 5.08 eV on the pure TiO2 surface. However, the free energy decreases to approximately 2.75 eV on TiO2/Ti3C2T x MXene composites. This indicates that the TiO2/Ti3C2T x MXene composites are predicted to be more active in the NRR than pure TiO2. As shown in Fig. 6(b), the hydrogenation of *NNH proceeds through two pathways: *NNH → *NNH2 and *NNH → *NHNH. For an alternative pathway, the *NHNH into *NHNH2 process is a downhill pathway with ΔG = −1.33 eV, which is lower than that of the distal pathway (*NNH2 into *N) with ΔG = 2.75 eV. The adsorption geometries of the intermediates on the TiO2/Ti3C2T x MXene composite surface along the alternating pathway are shown in Fig. 6(a). The above calculations reveal that the alternative pathway has been proved to be more energetically preferable over a distal pathway. As an alternative pathway, PDS is the formation of NH3 (1.36 eV) (Fig. 6(c)). Overall, our calculation results show that the addition of Ti3C2T x MXene into TiO2/Ti3C2T x MXene composites can increase the electrocatalytic efficiency for the NRR. 3 Conclusions In conclusion, we designed a novel TiO2/Ti3C2T x MXene composite and demonstrated that the composite has a high NRR activity in neutral media under ambient conditions. The TiO2/Ti3C2T x MXene catalyst could obtain a larger NH3 yield of 44.17 µg h−1 mg−1 cat. at −0.95 V vs. RHE and higher Faradaic efficiency (FE) of 44.68% at −0.75 V than those of pure Ti3C2T x and pure TiO2. In addition, the prepared catalysts exhibit remarkable selectivity and stability. The outstanding NRR activity can be ascribed to the following reasons: (1) The heterostructure formed by TiO2 NSs and Ti3C2T x MXene not only facilitates carrier transport in between but also avoids the microscopic stacking of Ti3C2T x MXene, which leads to rapid reaction kinetics at the heterogeneous interface. (2) The BET specific area of TiO2/Ti3C2T x MXene is larger than that of Ti3C2T x MXene owing to the generation of TiO2 NSs. Furthermore, the results of the isotope labeling experiment showed that the detected NH3 originated from the NRR and not from NO3 − or NH3 contaminants. DFT calculations showed that TiO2 NSs supported on Ti3C2T x MXene effectively enhanced the NRR performance owing to their stronger adsorption and lower energy barrier. coredata.dc:description: In this study, TiO2 nanosheets (NSs) grown in situ on extremely conductive Ti3C2T x MXene to form TiO2/Ti3C2T x MXene composites with abundant active sites are proposed to effectively achieve electrocatalytic NH3 synthesis. Electron transfer can be promoted by Ti3C2T x MXene with high conductivity. Meanwhile, the TiO2 NSs in-situ formation can not only avoid Ti3C2T x MXene microstacking but also enhance the surface specific area of Ti3C2T x MXene. The TiO2/Ti3C2T x MXene catalyst reaches a high Faradaic efficiency (FE) of 44.68% at −0.75 V vs. RHE and a large NH3 yield of 44.17 µg h−1 mg−1 cat. at −0.95 V, with strong electrochemical durability. 15N isotopic labeling experiments imply that the N in the produced NH3 originated from the N2 of the electrolyte. DFT calculations were conducted to determine the possible NRR reaction pathways for TiO2/Ti3C2T x MXene composites. MXene catalysts combined with other materials have been rationally designed for efficient ammonia production under ambient conditions.
coredata.prism:publisher: Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, the Chinese Academy of Sciences. Published by Elsevier B.V.
coredata.dc:title: Heterostructuring 2D TiO2 nanosheets in situ grown on Ti3C2T x MXene to improve the electrocatalytic nitrogen reduction
